clinical_study.brief_title: Carbon Dioxide Versus Air Insufflation in Oesophago-Gastro-Duodenoscopy (OGD)
clinical_study.official_title: A Double-Blinded, Randomized Trial Comparing Carbondioxide(CO2)and Air Insufflation in Oesophago-Gastro-Duodenoscopy (OGD)

lead_sponsor.agency: Norwegian Department of Health and Social Affairs

clinical_study.source: Norwegian Department of Health and Social Affairs

brief_summary.textblock:
To achieve a satisfactory examination of the GI tract it needs to be distended during endoscopic procedures. After the examinations many patients complain of abdominal pain and discomfort. This pain has been substantially reduced by substituting room air with CO2 in both colonoscopies and ERCPs. The use of CO2 during colonoscopy has become routine practice at many endoscopy centers.
In our study we will test the hypothesis that abdominal pain after gastroscopies also can be reduced by substituting room air with CO2.

intervention.intervention_name: Room air insufflation through the endoscopy rack
intervention.description: CO2 will be insufflated during oesophagogastroduodenoscopy in the intervention group, the control group will be examined with room air.

intervention.intervention_name: CO2 insufflation using an Olympus CO2 insufflator
intervention.description: From the CO2 rack through the endoscopy rack CO2 will be insufflated to visualize the mucosa during oesophagogastroduodenoscopy.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients scheduled for OGD at the outpatient clinic of Telemark Hospital
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age <18
- Inability to give an informed concent
- Unsatisfactory norwegian language skills
- Patients not willing to participate
- COPD with dyspnoea NYHA 3-4

responsible_party.organization: Southern and Eastern Norway Health Authority board
